nodes.bodyText:
I still need to ask Forge about this (if it's still the same in latest forge).
Do we care enough to exactly duplicate Forge's behavior here?
Let's report this to Forge if it's still an issue, as it is an inconsistency.
tbh I'm not certain about this injection. I think it works? might want to add a shift to after the call.

INVOKE_ASSIGN is a built in injection point that just puts it after the INVOKE call, that seems like what you want. The name seems odd, but the real name is AfterInvoke as opposed to BeforeInvoke (INVOKE's internal name)

INVOKE_ASSIGN results in a Critical injection failure: Variable modifier method hookApplyDamageForDamageEvent(FLnet/minecraft/entity/damage/DamageSource;)F in patchwork-events-entity.mixins.json:MixinLivingEntity failed injection check, (0/1) succeeded., whereas INVOKE just ends up working. also applies for MixinPlayerEntity. I tried this before-hand, and have now re-confirmed.
ditto about shift
Same response as the other one
ditto, same issue as with the other one.

forge issue 6227
Do we want to follow the suggested (stale) PR, or just leave it alone for now?

nodes.bodyText: So, I ended up creating two separate possible mixins for this. I currently like the latter more, as I feel like it's more robust, but I'm leaving the former in for now, in case its actually better. I will remove whichever one isn't used before merging.

Question about injection location. I kinda feel like injecting into the HEAD of ServerWorld.close would be marginally better than MinecraftServer.shutdown, but this is where forge does it, and it's not difficult to inject it here.
I ended up creating some mixins to handle some DimensionManager patches. I can totally remove them from this PR, just figured I'd leave them in in case they'd be useful in the future.
Currently, there's a minor locational difference between this mixin and forge. I don't think it'll have any side-effects, other than maybe being a bit inefficient.

... oops, i forgot to add all of the new mixins here, which means that it's even less tested than I thought. sigh
I'll come back to this later. I've already been working on this for hours in a row today.
